wikipedia_page.main: Edmund Nigel Ramsay Crisp, Baron Crisp  (born 14 January 1952) is a crossbench member of the House of Lords where he co chairs the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Global Health. He works and publishes extensively in global health and international development. He was a British senior civil servant in the Department of Health, public policy analyst, and Senior Manager in the NHS. He was awarded a life peerage upon retirement.

response: In April 2006, Hewitt made a speech in which she quoted Nigel Crisp's, the then current NHS chief executive, 2014 NHS annual report foreword, stating the NHS had had "its best year ever" and citing a decrease in waiting times for hospital treatment. However, this claim came at a time when thousands of jobs were being cut across the country as a number of NHS trusts attempted to cope with budget deficits. This comment did not go down well, and at the Royal College of Nursing 2006 Congress in Bournemouth, Hewitt was heckled and booed by health workers. Delegates at the conference called for job cuts and bed closures, part of planned NHS reforms aimed at improving the effectiveness of the service, to be halted, predicting that the number of posts lost could reach 13,000, and said a work to rule was possible.NHS Cash Crisis The Guardian, 24 April 2006. BMA chairman Mr. James Johnson claimed 2006 was actually one of the worst years on record and that "2006 has been full of bleak moments for the NHS – job losses, training budgets slashed, trusts delaying operations in order to save money and hospital closures announced at the same time as new PFI developments. Added to this the government's fixation with introducing the private sector into primary care which risks destabilising the well-respected UK system of general practice."2006: the best of years, the worst of years?  BMA, December 2006.

response: In 2008 Nursing Times named her the sixth most influential nurse of the last 60 years. In 2018 NHS England and Nursing Standard identified her as one of the 70 most influential UK nurses and midwives of the past 70 years, as part of the NHS 70th birthday celebrations. Nursing and healthcare development in the UK continued to be an important strand of her work, alongside her global health leadership. She joined the secretariat of the Prime Minister’s Commission on the Future of Nursing and Midwifery in England, 2009-2010, launched by Prime Minister Gordon Brown and chaired by Ann Keen MP. She also co-led the secretariat of the Willis Commission on Nursing Education, chaired by Lord Willis of Knaresborough. Its 2012 report, Quality with Compassion: the future of nursing education, found the case for moving to an all-graduate nursing profession not simply desirable, but essential. As policy advisor to the UK All-Party Parliamentary Group on Global Health, she worked closely with its chair Nigel Crisp on an influential review of global nursing, Triple Impact, which urged policy-makers worldwide to see nursing in a different light, and offered positive solutions and development opportunities. It provided a springboard for the global Nursing Now campaign, 2018-2021, and the declaration of 2020 as the International Year of the Nurse and Midwife. Salvage was active in shaping the campaign and wrote and spoke about it worldwide. Her talk at the University of Edinburgh inspired nurses to celebrate nursing by designing a new tartan incorporating the colours of Scotland’s national nurse uniform. From 2016-2021 she was director of the International Council of Nurses' Global Nursing Leadership Institute, an annual programme helping nurse leaders from round the world to improve their policy and political competencies. This contributed to her election as a Fellow of the Faculty of Nursing and Midwifery of the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland (RCSI) in 2019. In 2021 she was director of a pilot Midwifery Leadership Programme commissioned by the Government of India to take forward its Midwifery Initiative, implemented by the WHO Country Office for India. She has been a trustee and adviser to many governmental and charitable organizations including the Global Initiative on Psychiatry, Medact, the Queen’s Nursing Institute, and Fitzjohn's Food Bank, Lewes, East Sussex.
